author: anegwa

text:
Ah... I love this music.
This is the part of the game that I noticed that my favorite character was Midna. I had never worried so much about a character before. It was raining and, although we didn't had a timer, I was desperate to save her. It's pretty obvious that she can't die in this part, but I appreciate the fact that they didn't include a timer, because of the uncertainty, I didn't know if I had a time limit or not, so I just dashed through this part as fast as I could so that she wouldn't die.
I hate the fact that this music is interrupted by the battle music though, even on the HD Remake, it breaks the feeling completely, but this is still one of my favorite moments from all the games that I played.
Another thing thought, Midna's Desperation Hour (Midna's Lament) from Super Smash Bros. is a clearer version, it's, sadly, better than the game's version, you can notice how the melody from the piano is a bit muffed in this version.
author: Not A Cat

text:

author: J.M

text:
@MrZangetsu468 

You forgot the first and foremost definition of Sophisticated.

"(of a machine, system, or technique) Developed to a high degree of complexity."

Which in this case, this song is not, as it is repetitive and mellow.

I know you were talking about Zelda music, and this is not a sophisticated song.

It is in the emotional department? But other than that, this song is not developed to a high degree of complexity.

Wind Waker was more sophisticated in it's music.
author: Evan Smith

text:
@00Kirby0 "One of the most sophisticated Zelda tracks" is exactly what I said. I never spoke about music in general, I'm commenting specifically on a videogame here dumbass, if you misread it falls on you.

This music portrays Midna's emotional state at the time it is played during TP.

text: @TheCuster58 You're right, the Ice arrow is a "cool" example. The developers make sure it works decently, prolly in a menial way by shooting Ice arrows at any would-be targets in the entire game,. But the bow-arrow fundamental code and testing is already accounted for. All they need are a few extra graphical effects and a "stopper" for the moving enemy. Inserting "new" items by modifying old items, is not hard. Red bombs, anyone? Upgradable boomerang? If you have a gamemechanic, make use of it!

author: Mutooter

text: @SupraDarky It's a conundrum. If they have cool gear and items (Bomerang, bombs, hookshot) they want to make them useful in the game (stunnable enemies, breakable walls, attachable spots). But implementing items requires RL dev resources. Items in hidden caves are items the playersbase can miss and not experience. By putting nice items in mandatory temples they ensure that all players will enjoy them and other resources are used to improve the rest of the game. The music for example =)

author: thechcoman

text: @chcoman123 Like I said, they are BOTH correct. Midna's Lament and Midna's Desperate Hour are names for the same song. Not just one. Just because in America we call it, Midna's Lament doesn't mean that's the only name and real name. This happens a lot with other games when translating from Japanese to English. I've seen it countless times.

text: This music makes me think of walking down a road in the fall... with a lot of leaves falling down around me. By myself... a few kids playing games outside. I continue walking, emotionless, as if ignoring the children's joy, but I am not sad. The kids stop playing for a moment, and watch me walk by. I am empty.
author: Wyatt Kunzelman

Best song in the game. 

Twilight Princess was okay, though I'd still rank it lower than MM and maybe even WW. author: lismore1

text: As an aside, one thing I hope they fix in the next Zelda are the rewards you get outside the dungeons. It's a problem that's been present throughout most of the series, where I'll find a cool hidden cave or something. I go inside, there's a fun mini-labyrinth, and in the end all I get is either 100 Rupees (when I already have 999 so the chest stays closed) or a piece of heart. It's rarely a surprising reward.
author: SupraDarky

text: @Masz52 That's the thing though, for me Zelda is all about dungeons. It's the number one reason I love this series so much. Even then, while MM definitely had the upper hand in terms of things to do outside the dungeons, I spent a lot of fun time outside of them as well in TP. It had a lot of mini-games and hidden caves or spots you could go back to with your new dungeon treasures.
author: SupraDarky

text: @TalesOfGod Oh god I LOVE Majora's Mask. By far the most dynamic and interesting world in a 3D Zelda.

text: While OoT definitely had the bigger impact on me at the time, Twilight Princess is actually my favorite 3D Zelda (Link's Awakening being my favorite 2D Zelda). Few people usually agree with me.
